channel.title: BBC News

item.title: MI5 closely involved in handling of IRA spy Stakeknife, says report
item.description: The final report of Operation Kenova says the security service had "greater knowledge" of Stakeknife than it had at first stated.

item.title: No collusion between security forces and UVF in bombings - report
item.description: Detectives re-examined bombings in Dublin and Monaghan as part of a wide-ranging review of loyalist attacks in the 1970s.

item.title: Roads closed and flooding in some areas due to storm
item.description: A number of flights have been cancelled and several roads have been closed due to Storm Bram.

item.title: Police to get pay uplift as ministers allocate unspent money
item.description: The majority of the money will go towards health, education and justice where pressures over public sector pay rises have been most acute.

item.title: Cocaine widely detected in some of NI's major lakes and rivers
item.description: A study of five waterways, including the River Lagan and Lough Neagh, finds cocaine and its by-product in 91% of almost 140 water samples.

item.title: Key point of A5 appeal won't be heard immediately
item.description: Two government departments are now involved in the appeal of a ruling that blocked the project.

item.title: Racist violence by paramilitaries deeply worrying - report
item.description: Police intelligence pointed to the participation of individual loyalist paramilitary members during recent disorder.

item.title: Man arrested on suspicion of Lisa Dorrian's murder released
item.description: Lisa Dorrian was last seen alive in the early hours of 28 Feburary 2005 in Ballyhalbert in County Down.

item.title: Farmers 'lose thousands' as fair classes cancelled due to bluetongue
item.description: All bovine classes at the Royal Ulster Winter Fair have been cancelled due to bluetongue virus in NI.

item.title: School to stay shut until after Christmas due to roof concerns
item.description: More than 200 pupils of Nazareth House primary school in Derry have been off school since last week.

item.title: Airbus and Boeing complete acquisition of Spirit AeroSystems
item.description: Boeing and Airbus confirm completion of deal that sees Spirit operations in Belfast being split between the two companies.

item.title: Residents return to homes after second security alert ends
item.description: Homes in Havana Court were evacuated following a second security alert in the area

item.title: Presbyterian minister sexually assaulted me in 1970s, says woman
item.description: Maggie Montgomery said Reverend Poots was driving her home in 1978 when he sexually assaulted her.

item.title: Deputy first minister rejects 'panto season' claim over budget tensions
item.description: The deputy first minister was responding after leaked letters between the finance and education ministers laid bare tensions over Stormont's budget.

item.title: Soldier not to be prosecuted for killing man
item.description: William McGreanery, 41, died on 15 September 1971, after being shot by the Army in Londonderry.

item.title: Peter Robinson gives evidence to fraud trial
item.description: Peter Robinson told the trial he has known the accused, Frank Cushnahan, for over 30 years.

item.title: Almost half of planned new social homes at risk of not being built
item.description: The number of financially viable new social homes is projected to fall from 2,092 to 1,100, according to new research.

item.title: Ulster University freezes staff promotions over 'financial challenges'
item.description: Ulster University employs about 2,700 staff across its four campuses in Northern Ireland.

item.title: 'Elated but frustrated' our road has reopened after 20 months
item.description: The closure of the Glenshesk Road has meant 20 minute detours for local residents.

item.title: Friends and rivals - Wiffen and McMillan raise swimming's profile in NI
item.description: Daniel Wiffen and Jack McMillan are friends and rivals, but until the recent 400m final at the European Short Course Championships, they had yet to face one another at an international event.

item.title: Letters reveal tensions at Stormont over money allocation
item.description: Ministers are due to discuss funding issues this week, in what is known as a monitoring round.

item.title: New suspected case of bluetongue virus discovered
item.description: Vets are investigating a suspect case of the virus in a cow which sits in the existing 20km Temporary Control Zone (TCZ).

item.title: Kearney appointed manager of Ballymena United
item.description: Oran Kearney has been appointed as the new manager of Ballymena United.

item.title: Woman taken to hospital with serious injury following collision
item.description: A woman in her 20s, was taken to hospital with serious injuries following the two-vehicle collision in Lisnaskea.

item.title: Clerical abuse survivor calls for end to character references in sex offence cases
item.description: Tony Gribben says the Justice Minister should end or limit the use of character references in sex offence cases.

item.title: Man recovering from over-the-counter drug addiction urges others to get help
item.description: Addiction to over-the-counter drugs is "an increasing problem in Northern Ireland".

item.title: Fáilte Ireland expansion 'great opportunity' for NI
item.description: Fáilte Ireland, the Republic of Ireland's official tourism body, launched Hidden Heartlands in 2018 to promote the midland counties, which will now include Fermanagh, to visitors from around the world.

item.title: Chair and well fabled for 'healing powers' gets protected status
item.description: Local people have welcomed the official recognition of the historical significance of the ancient site.

item.title: 'It's not safe for my father to remain in Gaza'
item.description: Khalid Al-Estal, who is an Irish citizen, managed to get his two small children to Dublin in 2023, but two years later his father remains in Gaza.

item.title: BBC Newsline signed summary
item.description: A signed summary of BBC Newsline.

item.title: Will new signs be enough to stop car traffic on buzzing Belfast street?
item.description: Hill Street in Belfast's Cathedral Quarter will be pedestrianised for an initial six-month period.

item.title: BBC reports from family court case in NI media first
item.description: The case is part of a new media pilot scheme, introduced by the Lady Chief Justice to help reform the courts.

item.title: 'A way to honour our babies and recognise their loss'
item.description: Gemma McGibbon, who has had four miscarriages, says new certificates that acknowledge loss during pregnancy before 24 weeks will "honour those babies". Gemma McGibbon, 3

item.title: 'Palliative care in NI is a Cinderella service'
item.description: A widower shared his wife's story ahead of a report on access to palliative care services in NI.

item.title: BBC Newsline signed summary
item.description: A signed summary of BBC Newsline.

item.title: BBC Newsline signed summary
item.description: A signed summary of BBC Newsline.

item.title: Veteran civil rights campaigner Eamon Melaugh dies
item.description: Eamon Melaugh was heavily involved with the civil rights movement in Londonderry.

item.title: Soldier not to be prosecuted for killing man
item.description: William McGreanery, 41, died on 15 September 1971, after being shot by the Army in Londonderry.

item.title: Thousands participate in Apprentice Boys' parade
item.description: Around 2,500 Apprentice Boys and 24 bands are taking part in the annual event in the city.

item.title: 'My son is asking when his school will open again'
item.description: More than 200 pupils of Nazareth House primary school in Derry are at home for a second day because of concerns over the building's roof.

item.title: 'I can't wait to make my Northern Irish debut' - Opera star Tara Erraught
item.description: The internationally acclaimed singer performs at Londonderry's St Columb's Hall on Thursday.

item.title: Principal 'angered and saddened' by school roof safety closure
item.description: The principal of Nazareth House Primary School in Londonderry says she does not know when they will be able to reopen.

item.title: NI's 'worst road' fixed as new scheme aims to tackle potholes
item.description: Northern Ireland's road network will become the "most understood in the world" the company behind the scheme says.

item.title: At-large killer returned to prison after extradition
item.description: James Meehan appeared in court in Ballymena on Tuesday after he was extradited from the Republic of Ireland.

item.title: Appeal for information after man indecently exposed himself
item.description: Police are asking anyone who witnessed the incident or who may be aware of similar incidents, to come forward.

item.title: Man refuses to leave cell to face assault charge
item.description: A police officer sustained a serious hand injury in an assault in Londonderry on Saturday night.

item.title: Two dead after crash involving bus and car
item.description: The crash happened on the Derrylin Road near Enniskillen on Friday evening.

item.title: Teacher has jail term revoked for sex assault on child
item.description: A former music teacher at Erne Integrated College had his appeal against his sentence upheld.

item.title: Easter parade trial shown 'join the IRA' video
item.description: The four men - Thomas Ashe Mellon, Jason Lee Ceulemans, Patrick Anthony Gallagher and Stephen Martin Murney - deny the charges.

item.title: Attempted murder arrest after officer stabbed with hunting knife
item.description: Deputy Chief Constable Bobby Singleton said the attack highlights the risks many police officers face on a day-to-day basis.

item.title: Walled city's heritage brought to life in new 3D map
item.description: Using state-of-the-art scanning technology, Derry's historic walls have been recreated in a 3D map.

item.title: Seized pipe bombs contained ball bearings - trial told
item.description: The details were given at the trial of four men who deny charges linked to a dissident republican parade in Derry in 2023.

item.title: Trial begins for four accused over Derry Easter parade
item.description: The four men - Thomas Ashe Mellon, Jason Lee Ceulemans, Patrick Anthony Gallagher and Stephen Martin Murney - deny the charges.

item.title: Men jailed over unprovoked attack on drunk friend
item.description: Kieran Kelly and Dylan Quaile were both jailed for an unprovoked attack on a friend in September 2024

item.title: Drug-dealer jailed for role in organised crime gang
item.description: Jack Terence Boyd, 28, with an address at Maghaberry Prison, will spend two years in jail and two more on licence.

item.title: Murder probe after child and woman die in Offaly house fire
item.description: Mary Holt, aged 60, and Tadhg Farrell, aged four, died in a house fire in County Offaly.

item.title: Evidence of burial ground at Tuam mother and baby home
item.description: Agency said it found "graves of child or infant size" at an area on the western edge of the site.

item.title: Irish police investigating drone activity during Zelensky visit
item.description: The Irish police force says it is investigating the matter after reports of drones near Dublin around the time the Ukrainian president landed.

item.title: Boycotts and arguments - can the Eurovision Song Contest survive its biggest crisis?
item.description: The biggest crisis in the Eurovision Song Contest's history raises major questions about its future.

item.title: Irish battalion safe after coming under fire in south Lebanon
item.description: A Defence Forces spokesperson said the 127 Infantry Battalion came under fire while conducting a patrol.

item.title: Ireland boycotts Eurovision after Israel allowed to compete
item.description: There had been calls for Israel's exclusion over the war in Gaza, as well as unfair voting accusations.

item.title: Senior Irish government figures briefed on drone presence during Zelensky visit
item.description: The Irish Defence Forces says it had no comment on "any alleged incidents" during the visit.

item.title: How the Irish border was created
item.description: The Boundary Commission plan to adjust the border and remove places from NI was ditched in a British-Irish deal

item.title: Some Irish officers to get tasers in new six-month pilot scheme
item.description: The six-month scheme, set to roll out in Dublin, Waterford and Kilkenny will see about 128 officers given the stunguns.

item.title: Ireland to give €125m to Ukraine as Zelensky visits Dublin
item.description: The announcement was made by Taoiseach Micheál Martin at a press conference on Tuesday.

item.title: TV architect Hugh Wallace dies, aged 68
item.description: Hugh Wallace, 68, was best known for presenting RTÉ's Home of the Year and the BBC's The Great House Revival

item.title: Council removes proposal to rename park named after former president of Israel
item.description: The park is named after Belfast-born and Dublin-raised Chaim Herzog, a former president of Israel.

item.title: Crumbling homes redress payouts top €230m
item.description: Campaigners say too many families in the Republic of Ireland remain in unsafe homes this winter.

item.title: CMAT, Fontaines D.C. and Gorillaz to play Electric Picnic 2026
item.description: Electric Picnic will take place from 28 August to 30 August 2026 at Stradbally Hall, County Laois.

item.title: Report in relation to renaming Herzog Park set to be withdrawn
item.description: The park is named after Belfast-born and Dublin-raised Chaim Herzog, a former president of Israel.

item.title: Israeli president concerned over proposed renaming of park
item.description: The park is named after Belfast-born and Dublin-raised Chaim Herzog, a former president of Israel.

item.title: 'Callous' beheading of stag prompts police investigation
item.description: The headless body of the stag, that was part of the herd at Newbridge Demesne in Dublin, was found by staff on Thursday.

item.title: Son given life sentence for murdering his 75-year-old mother
item.description: Miriam Burns died from asphyxia due to manual strangulation along with blunt force trauma to her head.

item.title: Wrong anthem played at Republic of Ireland game
item.description: The Republic of Ireland's players sung an a cappella version of the national anthem after God Save the King was played by mistake ahead of a Women's Under-19 European qualifier.
